text: my name is Chris line I'm VP of cloud
engineering and security at Lookout when
I was brought on two and a half years
ago one of my missions was to migrate
our entire workload into AWS our
infrastructure about started in data
centers and up to about six months ago
we actually had presents inside of a
data center we are fully now inside of
AWS AWS gives us a platform that we can
deliver features deliver capabilities
for our our customers in a faster more
agile way where our data center was
slowing us down
it was proving to be less ideal for
spinning up new services for iterating
fast and really our decision to move
into AWS was around velocity and
business there's a number of features
that we have that have increased our
velocity when you look at RDS for
instance you know we don't need to have
in-depth knowledge of doing databases
sail overs maintaining backups that is
less cost for us and more efficiency the
decision to use Aurora was around a
couple points first off it supported the
multiple multiple terabytes that we
required as well as it gave us the
ability to do fail over and multi-region
data replication these were features
that were not something that we were
willing to build on our own we're also
using enterprise support for a number of
our accounts and services inside of AWS
our Tam that's been assigned to us has
been amazing and the support that we get
has been topped here so by moving to AWS
we've been able to move quicker deliver
features and capabilities to our
customers faster than we could have
inside of our own data center and that's
been able to help secure the hundred
million users that we have
and in a mobile world securing those
devices is what lookout brings
